title: Florida Democrats learn from past failures as they prepare 2020 strategy
text:
While Florida Democrats have united to build their 2020 election infrastructure, they’re divided over whether a progressive or moderate presidential nominee can do more to help the party’s chances. | Stan Honda/AFP/Getty Images Florida Democrats learn from past failures as they prepare 2020 strategy

LAKE BUENA VISTA — More than 1,500 Florida Democrats gathered for their annual convention this weekend at a Mexican-themed resort at Walt Disney World, where they danced to disco, chowed down on free food, and indulged in ice cream and cupcakes courtesy of two presidential candidates.

But the festivities weren’t enough to dispel a sense of unease that has gripped Florida Democrats as President Donald Trump ramps up his bid for re-election. Hanging over this year’s gathering was a central, disturbing question: What if? What if Democrats are doomed to lose here yet again in 2020?

Story Continued Below

“I’m very worried about this election,” said U.S. Rep. Donna Shalala (D-Fla.). “We have to inspire people and they have to get out and vote. We have the votes to win Florida but we have to turn out.”

Florida is ground zero for Trump’s re-election, and for Democrats it seems like an eternity since former President Barack Obama forged a winning coalition to win the state twice.

Trump won Florida in 2016 with less than half of the popular vote, edging out Democrat Hillary Clinton by fewer than 113,000 votes of 9.4 million cast. It was an agonizing defeat that Democrats re-lived again in 2018, when gubernatorial candidate Ron DeSantis, a Republican, defeated Democrat Andrew Gillum by only 32,463 votes.

With their razor-thin losses racking up, Democratic leaders are trying to shake the party’s lather-rinse-repeat cycle. Election Day is more than a year away, but they’ve already ramped up voter registration efforts, boosted outreach to Hispanics, and started a “voter protection” team of volunteer lawyers ready to go into battle. During one panel this weekend, lawyers working with the party urged county party members to check ballot designs, which some suspect might have cost Democrats votes in Broward County.

“We have learned our lesson,” said Juan Peñalosa, executive director of the Florida Democratic Party.

The party is spending $3.2 million on voter registration, a basic element of successful campaigns or, as one Democratic consultant put it, “blocking and tackling.”

“The party is kind of getting back to our roots,” said Peñalosa. “That’s focusing on voter registration, building neighborhood teams, precinct captains, expanding our base, and not waiting until we have a candidate.”

Still, skepticism was evident at this weekend’s gathering. During one training session, activists asked how to motivate voters demoralized by recent losses. In the past two governor’s races, voters cast 14.1 million ballots; Democrats lost by a collective 96,608 votes.

In 2018, when Gillum fell to DeSantis, Democratic Sen. Bill Nelson, the state party’s longtime leader, lost to now-Sen. Rick Scott by about 10,000 votes, triggering a recount and legal battles. Agriculture Commissioner Nikki Fried was the only Democrat to take statewide office that year, winning by a 6,753 vote margin.

A year before Obama’s 2012 win in Florida, the party registered 60,000 voters. In the year leading up to the 2016 election, they registered 11,000, and just 7,000 a year before the 2018 election.

“We know how 2016 and 2018 went,” Peñalosa said.

So far this year, Republican have registered about 1,000 more voters than Democrats, but state Democrats contend that they’ve taken a slight advantage since they launched their voter registration campaign in early June.

Since then, Democrats have registered nearly 900 more voters than Republicans, according to voter registration numbers posted by state officials.

It’s about learning from past mistakes, including timing, said Florida Democratic Party chair Terrie Rizzo.

“That’s one reason we are doing what we are doing now, why we are building programs now,” she said. “If you look around the room, there’s actually tremendous enthusiasm.”

Another pitfall of recent cycles has been Hispanic outreach. The Hispanic vote has been a persistent problem for Florida Democrats and helped Scott rack up a 3-0 record. Older Cuban-Americans turn out in high numbers for Republicans while younger Cubans and non-Cuban Hispanics who skew Democratic are less likely to vote.

“We have a lack of Spanish-speaking surrogates for media in the Florida Democratic Party,” Peñalosa said. “We have had a concerted effort to kind of train up Spanish speaking media surrogates.”

The party has added a Spanish-language communications staffer, and of the 31 organizers in targeted areas of the state, half speak Spanish, Creole, or both.

While Florida Democrats have united to build their 2020 election infrastructure, they’re divided over whether a progressive or moderate presidential nominee can do more to help the party’s chances.

“We are going to have to create space for people who voted for Barack Obama once or twice and then voted for Trump,” said Steve Schale, a political strategist who helmed Obama’s state campaign in 2008 and is now backing Vice President Joe Biden.

That means making inroads in Republican-dominated counties so they don’t deliver huge margins for Trump.

“We are not going to win in Florida if we lose Pasco County by 50,000 votes again,” Schale said.

Biden and Massachusetts Sen. Elizabeth Warren had the biggest presence at this weekend’s convention. Both had staff on the ground, noticeable supporter presence, and raucous rallies in the conventional hall on Saturday afternoon

The Biden team believes a candidate seen as too far to the left will turn off non-progressive Democrats. Warren supporters say Floridians want a progressive candidate who could excite those voters and motivate them to turn out.

To make their point, Warren’s camp points to Gillum’s 2018 campaign. Gillum ran as a progressive during both the primary and general elections, besting Gwen Graham, a former Democratic congresswoman and party favorite, and almost taking the governor’s mansion.

“Bernie [Sanders] laid the groundwork in 2016. He did not do as well as many wanted, but the groundwork was laid,” said Jody Young, lead volunteer coordinator for Warren’s Florida campaign. “Gillum certainly surprised a lot of people.”

“I was working for Gwen at the time,” Young said. “They just out-hustled us. He laid more groundwork for progressives.”

Christian Ulvert, a South Florida Democratic consultant, said his party recognizes its recent missteps. But he warned that Democrats can’t wait for their candidate to be nominated to before they push back on Republican’s “socialist” branding of the party.

“We’ve got to turn it up a notch or two,” he said. “2020 is right around the corner.”
description: The festivities weren’t enough to dispel a sense of unease that has gripped Florida Democrats as President Donald Trump ramps up his bid for re-election.
